description.en: This course aims to provide an overview of a number of protracted regional conflicts in Eurasia. We will examine closely conflicts ranging from North and South Caucasus to Transnistria, and from Ukraine/Crimea to Central Asia, from the collapse of the Soviet Union until today. More specifically, we will apply conflict assessment toolbox, and analyse dividers and connectors, principal players and secondary actors, drivers of conflict and peace, and finally, windows of vulnerability and opportunity in these regional conflicts.
description.et: Kursus käsitleb mitmeid pikaajalisi ja raskesti juhitavaid regionaalseid konflikte Kesk-Aasias, Lõuna- ja Põhja-Kaukaasias, Transnistrias ja Ukrainas/Krimmis. Nende ("külmutatud") konfliktide analüüsimisel lahatakse teemasid, mis on olnud vastuolude põhjustajateks ja koostöö takistajateks; põhilisi ja teisejärgulisi osalejaid ja nende huvisid; samuti seda, kuidas osalejatel on õnnestunud mobiliseeruda konfliktiks ja pidurdada rahuotsinguid; ning viimaks, millised on konflikti lahendamise väljavaated.

objectives.en: This course aims to provide an overview of a number of protracted regional conflicts in Eurasia, to introduce their key players and their main stakes, and to critically analyse the conflict management perspectives. The course seeks to apply conflict assessment toolbox in the empirical analysis of the post-Soviet region conflicts.
objectives.et: Interaktiivse kursuse eesmärgiks on anda ülevaade kestvatest regionaalsetest konfliktidest Euraasias ja tutvustada nende osapooli ning nende peamisi huvisid. Kursuse käigus kasutatakse konflikti analüüsi meetodit hindamaks võimalike lahenduste väljavaadet.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon completion of the course, the students will:
1) have a comprehensive empirical understanding of the major regional conflicts in the former Soviet space;
learning_outcomes.et: 1) saab põhjalikud teadmised suurematest regionaalsetest konfliktidest endise N. Liidu aladel;

learning_outcomes.en: 2) be able to analyse these frozen and on-going conflicts through conflict assessment toolbox;
learning_outcomes.et: 2) oskab analüüsida külmutatud ja käimasolevaid konflikte spetsiaalsele analüüsimeetodile tuginedes;

learning_outcomes.en: 3) situate the texts read in the framework of the course and their authors in wider intellectual contexts;
learning_outcomes.et: 3) suudab asetada loetud tekstid ja omandatud teadmised konfliktidest laiemasse intellektuaalsesse konteksti;

learning_outcomes.en: 4) formulate, present and defend specific arguments in oral and written formats alike;
learning_outcomes.et: 4) formuleerida, esitada ja kaitsta argumente suulises ja kirjalikus vormis;

learning_outcomes.en: 5) put forth a clear and well-argued policy advice on conflict management.
learning_outcomes.et: 5) ettevalmistada selgelt argumenteeritud poliitilisi nõuaandeid konfliktide ohjamisest.

independent_work.et:
The course is going to be interactive, combining lecture style presentations and discussion, with an emphasis on the latter. Students will be encouraged to apply their own insights to the conflicts under the discussions, and to amplify and clarify the points made by the lecturer. Small group discussions are encouraged throughout the course.

Students arrive in seminars having completed all the required readings and ready to contribute to a general discussion loosely organised around the study questions suggested beforehand by the instructor. Each student should have a couple of questions to offer for group discussion and analysis weekly. Every student is expected to speak in every seminar. Each session will be kicked off with a 30 minute presentation of the timeline of the key events and core issues in the conflict under discussion, including also actors' motives and settlement perspectives. The follow-up seminars will broaden the discussion on other specific aspects relevant to conflict dynamics. Active and meaningful participation in seminars is worth 20% of the final grade of the course.

Learning to read and digest critically academic texts and putting forth informed arguments in writing assignments is an important study goal of this course. This course has one written assignment:
1) a policy paper (7-9 pages), advising the European Union on one of the following topics:
(a) taking a particular action vis-à-vis the Ukrainian-Russian crisis; 
(b) revisi(ti)ng its neighbourhood policy in light of the wars in Georgia (2008) and Ukraine (2014);
(c) reinventing its Russia-policy in light of the frozen conflicts in Eurasia in general.

The aim of this exercise is to learn to present background information concisely and clearly for a time-deprived expert audience, to analyse the ongoing conflicts in Eurasia with clear policy implications in mind for the foreign policy actor on whom the students might actually have the greatest leverage in spe (i.e. the EU), and to put forth a clear and well-argued policy advice. This exercise will be worth 80% of the final grade. The particular requirements for this paper will be discussed in class in due course.

description.et: Policy paper (max 80 points): written assignment will be evaluated on how cogently and thoughtfully the topics are analyzed, how accurately evidence is interpreted and credible sources are incorporated, and whether the reasoning, findings and recommendations are sound.

grade_preconditions.et: Seminars are compulsory; only fully completed attendance allows access to the final grading. All absences can be compensated by answering the seminar questions in written form.

grade_evaluation.et:
Seminar participation - 20% of the final grade
Policy paper - 80% of the final grade

debt_elimination.et: Upon the agreement with the instructor.

description.et:
Introduction: Defining the Region, Delimiting the Conflicts, Designing Policy Advice
Reading list:
1. Buzan, Barry and Ole Wæver (2003). The Post-Soviet Space: A Regional Security Complex Around Russia, from Regions and Powers: The Structure of International Security. Cambridge: CUP (pp. 397-436).
2. Fischer, Sabine (2016). Russian Policy in the Unresolved Conflicts, in S. Fischer (ed) Not Frozen! The Unresolved Conflicts over Transnistria, Abkhazia, South Ossetia and Nagorno-Karabakh in Light of the Crisis over Ukraine. SWP Research Paper, 9-24.

South-Caucasus I: Nagorno-Karabakh Conflict.
Reading list:
1. Voronkova, Anastasia (2013). Nationalism and Organized Violence in Nagorno-Karabakh: A Microspatial Perspective, Nationalism and Ethnic Politics, 19:1, 102-118
2. Nagorno-Karabakh's Gathering War Clouds. International Crisis Group Europe Report N°244, 1 June 2017

South Caucasus II: Abkhazia, South Ossetia, Russo-Georgian War of 2008.
Reading list:
1. Hopf, T. (2005). Identity, Legitimacy, and the U se of Military Force: Russia's Great Power Identities and Military Intervention in Abkhazia. Review of International Studies, Vol. 31, pp. 225-243.
2. Toal, Gerard (2009). Russia's Kosovo: A Critical Geopolitics of the August 2008 War over South Ossetia. Eurasian Geography and Economics, 49(6): 670-705.
3. Abkhazia: Long Road to Reconciliation. Crisis Group Europe Report N°224, 10 April 2013.

The Spread of Violence in North Caucasus: Chechnya and Dagestan.
Reading list:
1. Kolossov, Vladimir & Gerard Toal (2007). An Empire's Fraying Edge? The North Caucasus Instability in Contemporary Russian Geopolitical Culture, Eurasian Geography and Economics, 48:2, 202-225
2. Hansen, Lars Funch (2012). Renewed Circassian Mobilization in the North Caucasus 20-years after the Fall of the Soviet Union, Journal on Ethnopolitics and Minority Issues in Europe 11(2), 103-135.
3. The North Caucasus: The Challenges of Integration (I), Ethnicity and Conflict, Crisis Group Europe Report N°220, 19 October 2012.

Moldova and Transnistria.
Reading list:
1. Troebst, Stefan (2003). "We Are Transnistrians!" Post-Soviet Identity Management in the Dniester Valley, Ab Imperio,  N°1, 437-466.
2. Moldova's Uncertain Future. Crisis Group Europe Report N°175, 17 August 2006.
3. Popescu, Nicu (2012). Transnistria: A Bottom-up Solution. ECFR Policy Brief N°63.

Central Asian Conflicts.
Reading list:
1. Allison, Roy (2004). Strategic Reassertion in Russia's Central Asia Policy, International Affairs 80(2): 277-293.
2. Lynch, Dov (2001). The Tajik Civil War and Peace Process, Civil Wars, 4(4), 49-72,
3. Stress Tests for Kazakhstan, Europe and Central Asia Briefing N°74, 13 May 2015.
4. Kyrgyzstan: An Uncertain Trajectory, Europe and Central Asia Briefing N°76, 30 September 2015.

Crimea and East Ukrainian Separatism of 2014.
Reading list:
1. Biersack, John and Shannon O'Lear (2014). The Geopolitics of Russia's Annexation of Crimea: Narratives, Identity, Silences, and Energy. Eurasian Geography and Economics 55(3), 247-269
2. Ukraine: Running out of Time. International Crisis Group Europe Report N°231, 14 May 2014.
3. Ukraine: Military Deadlock, Political Crises. International Crisis Group Europe Briefing N°85, 19 December 2016.

Wrap-up Discussion
Reading list:
1. Toal, Gerard (2017). Why Does Russia Invade Its Neighbours?, from Near Abroad: Putin, the West and the Contest over Ukraine and the Caucasus. Oxford University Press, 17-54.
2. Coyle, James (2017). Conclusion, from Russia's Border Wars and Frozen Conflicts, Palgrave Macmillan, 257-273.
